column1: Aside from the common bruise, bleeding into the skin or mucous membranes is a very significant sign and should always be checked out by a health care provider.

Some of them are: - Injury or trauma - Allergic reaction - Autoimmune disorders - Viral infection or illness affecting blood clotting (coagulation) - Thrombocytopenia - Medical treatment, including radiation and chemotherapy - Antiplatelet medicines such as clopidogrel (Plavix) - Bruise (ecchymosis) - Birth (petechiae in the newborn) - Aging skin (ecchymosis) - Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (petechiae and purpura) - Henoch-Schonlein purpura (purpura) - Leukemia (purpura and ecchymosis) - Medicines.
Anticoagulants such as warfarin or heparin (ecchymosis), aspirin (ecchymosis), steroids (ecchymosis).
Contact your health care provider if: - You have sudden bleeding into the skin for no apparent reason - You notice unexplained bruising that does not go away
- Do you take Coumadin, heparin, or other "blood thinners" (anticoagulants)?
